Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Searching for Preferred Directions in Space and Time
Award.AbstractNarration:
Two experiments will be pursued that test the fundamental underlying symmetries of nature. The first of these experiments will look for a preferred direction in the universe. This is accomplished by precisely measuring the energy of a mercury nucleus as a function of the alignment of its spin with respect to the fixed stars. The existence of such a preferred spatial direction violates the principle of Local Lorentz Invariance (LLI), one of the underlying symmetries of most current physical theories. The second experiment searches for a permanent electric dipole moment (edm) of the electron using a ceramic material called gadolinium iron garnet. This is a novel approach to one of the greatest experimental challenges in physics. The existence of a non-zero edm of a fundamental particle would violate the principle of time-reversal invariance.

Observation of a violation of either of the above symmetries of nature would radically alter our understanding of the physical world. String theory and supersymmetry remain two of the most attractive theories in particle physics, though both have proven to be very difficult to test. It has been suggested that string theory might allow for a violation of local Lorentz invariance at a level close to that which will be probed in the LLI experiment. Similarly, supersymmetry predicts an electron electric dipole moment very close to the level that will be probed in the edm search. The LLI experiment may result in further improvements in precise optically pumped magnetometers. The edm experiment will stretch our understanding of electromagnetic interactions at the surfaces of the iron garnets. This improved understanding might be important in future magnetic information storage devices. Both of these experiments will provide valuable training to undergraduates.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 The laws of physics are thought to be independent of the direction you orient your apparatus with respect to the universe. This is one aspect of a symmetry of nature that we refer to as "Local Lorentz Invariance" or LLI. Particles with spin precess about an applied magnetic field (like a spinning gyroscope precesses about a gravitational field) with a well defined frequency. By measuring this precession frequency precisely, one can create highly sensitive atomic magnetometers. In our work, we compare the spin-precession frequencies of mercury (199Hg) and cesium (Cs) atoms. Cs has an unpaired valence electron that accounts for nearly all of its interaction with the external magnetic field. However, in 199Hg all of the electrons are paired with their spins opposed and there is no net "electronic" spin. In 199Hg the spin interaction is associated with the protons and neutrons that make up the nucleus. In our experiment we measure the Cs and 199Hg spin precession frequencies as a function of the direction of an applied magnetic field with respect to the fixed stars. If their relative frequencies change with direction, this would be a violation of LLI and an indication of a "preferred direction in the universe". In an earlier experiment, we searched for this change, using the EarthÆs rotation to change the direction of our magnetic field with respect to the stars. This worked well, but was limited by the slow rate at which the Earth rotated. To solve this problem, we mounted our entire apparatus on a rotating "Lazy Susan". On this table we were able to rotate the direction of the applied field every 8 minutes rather than having to wait 24 hours for the rotation of the Earth. We collected 12 data runs with this second-generation apparatus over a period of a year, where each run consisted of four or five days of data collection. In the end, we did not observe any significant change in the relative frequencies that depended on the orientation of our experiment with respect to the stars. However, with this more rapid reversal of our apparatus, we did succeed in improving our sensitivity to LLI violating effects in the equatorial plane by about a factor of four. The rotating apparatus also allowed us to place the first constraints on the possibility that the preferred axis for the proton and neutron might lie along the spin axis of the Earth. When we asked ourselves the question of what might be interesting about this direction, we came up with the intriguing possibility that a frequency shift associated with a direction relative to the Earth could be associated with a long-range interaction between the spin-oriented electrons within the Earth and the spins in our apparatus. Long-range spin-spin interactions can arise from a variety of possible extensions beyond the standard model of particle physics. Physicists describe the spin-spin interactions associated with magnetism as being created by the exchange of "virtual" photons. Anomalous long-range spin-spin interactions could be created by the virtual exchange of other exotic particles such as a light neutral vector boson (called the zÆ) or an "unparticle". Some have suggested that the very structure of space might acquire a twist in the presence of spin in the same way as space becomes curved by the presence of mass in General Relativity. These "torsion gravity" models can also produce long-range spin-spin interactions. If any one of these long-range spin-spin interactions does exist, it would create an interaction between the oriented electron spins in the Earth and the spins in our apparatus. The unpaired electron-spins in the Earth become slightly oriented in the presence of the EarthÆs magnetic field. ...
